children.subject: Thanks for this great question. At this time, I'm working with the faculty who are designing the class to figure out what restrictions, if any, will be placed on EE 16A enrollments. I'll keep you posted as soon as I know the answer!
What are my chances of getting into EE16A next Spring and what should I do if I realllly want to enrol

Hello;

An announcement will be sent out today about the application process for the pilot version of 16A. While the course will not be restricted to freshmen, preference will be given to freshmen. The course is designed to serve students in their first year, so for the pilot, the faculty are attempting to get a realistic understanding of how the class should run. 

This course is a pilot, and as previously announced, it will be small (no more than 75 seats) so there will be lots of eager students who may not get into the pilot version. I understand that this may be disappointing. Please know that this will not be your only opportunity to take EE 16A; I expect it should grow significantly for Fall 2015. 

If you have questions about how you should plan your own coursework, please do not hesitate to contact me! 

Thanks,

Sarah

I've heard that EE 16a will only be offered to freshmen.  Why is this?  This makes it difficult for those of us who are sophomores planning to take our first EE course because we risk not finishing the 20/40 series in time if tele bears dates don't cooperate or we have to defer our first EE courses until junior year if we want to play it safe.  Restricting this 16a to freshmen seems unnecessary and just inconveniences us.
It will be open to both EECS and L&S CS freshmen. Thanks for asking! Once our faculty send out the announcement, I will post it here.
Thanks a lot.
I heard only EECS freshman can take it. Is it true? Or L&S Cs can also take it???
what is the max number of character I can put in Google Docs??? I only have 80 words but it reports that I have reached the maximum number of characters allowed.

Hmmm... thanks for letting me know. It's supposed to be 300 characters, but I'll bump it up now :) 

Sarah
Done
Thx

Dear Students,
 
The EE16 team is excitedly gearing up for offering the EE16A pilot in Spring 2015, and we're thrilled to see very high levels of interest.  Our goal is to run the pilot as smoothly as and as close to the final product possible, but as a pilot offering there may still be some rough edges.
 
Enrollment in the pilot will be handled via an off-TeleBEARS process. So, if you are interested in taking EE 16A in Spring 2015, please submit an application here and make sure you add yourself to the waitlist on TeleBEARS. The application is very short and we'll be using the information you provide to select roughly 60-70 participants. The deadline for submitting an application will be Friday, October 24th at 5pm. We will notify students who have been selected by Monday, November 3rd.
 
In order to get a representative and diverse group of students for our pilot, the selection process will be mostly random.  Note however that preference will be given to freshmen, and that students who have already taken EE 20 or 40 should not apply.  Furthermore, we will be reading your responses to the “Why do I want to participate in this pilot” question, so it is worth thinking about and clearly expressing that in the application.
 
If you have any follow-up questions regarding this process or EE16 overall, please direct them to Sarah Van Nostrand in the EECS department (svannostrand@eecs.berkeley.edu), or to myself (elad@eecs.berkeley.edu).
Hello, I increased the limit already; let me know if it doesn't work...

This did not work, I still cannot submit it.  I have used a word counter and am under the 150 word maximum, and it says "maximum characters exceeded."  Perhaps it needs to be by words, and not characters on the google form.
Did others experience the same thing? I'm triple checking and the word count has been increased. Have you tried refreshing the application, or closing it and opening it back up?

The error message I am getting is not about word count, but about character count.  I have 140 words.  I have just tried to submit it again, and received the same error message.  I done all of the following, and none of them work: 1) Simply refresh application 2) Close/reopen application 3) Log out and do the previous two options.

If, as you mentioned before, the limit is 300 characters, then I clearly see why it will not take my application - I have more than 300 characters.  But I have less than 150 words as specified by the application!

Apologies, I should have said I've adjusted the character count, not the word count. I'm really sorry for your frustration! I can understand why you're frustrated. I can see from the application that others have been able to successfully submit more than 300 characters. If you like, you can send me the remainder of your text via email and I can add it to your application- svannostrand@eecs.berkeley.edu. If others encounter this problem, please do let me know. On my end it looks like the character limit is at 750...

Thanks,

Sarah

Well, that clears things up.  My 140 word answer had more than 750 characters, I had to reduce it to 130 words in order to fit under the character limit.  It has now been submitted.  

It might be wise to state the 750 character limit on the application for future applicants though!
Thanks for the feedback, this has been updated on the application.

Can the character count be increased?  150 words/300 characters is on average 2 characters per word!  In order to use regular-size words that are not two characters long, we can only type a sentence or two!
You will get results by the end of the day today (11/3).
When can I get the result whether I am chosen by 16A or not?

history.content:
Dear EECS Students; 
On behalf of EECS chair Tsu-Jae King Liu, I wanted to make you aware of some exciting course updates. As you may have heard, our faculty are developing two new courses, EE 16A and B, which will eventually replace EE 20 and 40. These courses are designed to be more hands-on than their predecessors, and will allow students to be introduced to EE concepts earlier in their academic careers. These courses will not formally require physics or math as a prerequisite, although they do require some math maturity and aptitude (equivalent to math 1a and math 1b) in order to be successful. Here are some frequently asked questions to help you understand this transition. 
When do the new courses begin? 
EE 16A is expected to be offered for the first time in Spring 2015, and EE 16B will be offered beginning Fall 2015. In Spring of 2015, EE 16A will be introduced as a pilot program and is expected to offer seats for approximately 50 students.
When will the old courses expire?
The last term in which EE 20 and 40 will be offered is Fall of 2015. It is unlikely that these courses will be available after Fall 2015. 
Which sequence is the right one for me?
If you have already taken EE 20 or 40, you should plan on finishing the sequence before they expire. You must complete both courses in a sequence (EE 20 AND 40/ EE 16A AND B). Substitutions are not allowed. Continuing students and transfer students who have taken either EE 20 or 40 are encouraged to finish out the sequence before these courses disappear in Fall of 2015. Incoming Freshmen should plan to wait until Spring 2015 (or later) to take EE 16A. 
Will the new courses be the same size as the old courses?
In Spring 2015 we will offer a limited-enrollment pilot program of EE 16A, which we expect will seat approximately 50 students. Eventually, we expect EE 16A and B to scale to the size of EE 20 and 40. 

If you have additional questions, please don't hesitate to contact Sarah Van Nostrand in the EECS department at svannostrand@eecs.berkeley.edu. 
*** Please note: these updates are intended for declared EECS majors. L&S CS majors or intended majors should defer to course-taking advice from Christopher Hunn or Lily Zhang.
history.subject: Update on EE 16A and B
